citation.article-title: Robiginitomaculum antarcticum gen. nov., sp. nov., a member of the family Hyphomonadaceae, from Antarctic seawater
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Robiginitomaculum (Ro.bi.gi.ni.to.ma.cul′um. L. n. robigo -inis rust; L. neut. n. tomaculum a kind of sausage; N.L. neut. n. Robiginitomaculum a rust-coloured sausage).
Cells are Gram-negative, non-motile, non-budding, thin prostheca-producing, obligately aerobic rods or vibrioids.
Flagella and holdfast are not present.
Some cells possess a thin prostheca that extends along the long cell axis from one pole.
Bacteriochlorophyll a and the genes (pufLM) for anoxygenic photosynthesis are not found.
The predominant fatty acids are C18 : 1ω7c, C17 : 1ω8c, C17 : 0 and C17 : 1ω6c.
The major respiratory quinone is Q-10.
The DNA G+C content is 60.3 mol%.
The genus is phylogenetically assigned to the family Hyphomonadaceae in the order Rhodobacterales.
The type species of the genus is Robiginitomaculum antarcticum.
